I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Road crashes are increasing rapidly in most developing countries of Asia. A World 
Health Organization (WHO) analysis indicates that about 500,000 people are killed in road 
crashes in Asia each year.1 Thus, Asia produces approximately 44% of the world’s road deaths, 
despite having only 16% of the vehicle fleet. Fatality rates are excessive, frequently exceeding 
by 20–30 times those recorded in the countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation 
and Development (OECD). Trend data shows that the number of people killed annually in road 
crashes in Asia continues to increase, while OECD countries have seen a steady decline. 
Moreover,  the  experience  in  OECD  countries  suggests  that  many  road  accidents  are 
preventable.  
 
2.  With rapid motorization in Asia, road safety has become a significant sector issue. 
Despite efforts in some countries to address the road safety problem, information and data on 
the adverse impacts of road crashes are scarce. Crash statistics in most developing member 
countries  (DMCs)  are  poor,  and  often  significantly  underreport  the  number  of  deaths  and 
injuries. However, available data indicates that the majority of crashes involve pedestrians in 
rural areas. The poor face significantly higher risks of being involved in road accidents because 
they tend to live and work adjacent to roads and form the bulk of pedestrians. Many are heads 
of households, and their deaths often significantly reduce family incomes. Serious injuries have 
also  long-term  impacts  on  household  incomes  for  low-income  households,  and  can  have 
serious consequences on the household quality of life. While road crashes and poverty appear 
to be strongly linked, little empirical evidence is available on the socioeconomic impact of road 
crashes.  To  investigate  the  relationship  between  road  crashes  and  poverty,  the  United 
Kingdom’s Department for International Development agreed in January 2004 to include this 
study under the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund (PRF).2 Following an agreement that the 
study should examine different countries where road safety was a serious problem, four DMCs 
were selected—India, Indonesia, Pakistan, and Viet Nam. The Fact-Finding Mission was fielded 
in December 2004 to discuss the objectives of the regional technical assistance (TA), and to 
confirm the scope of work, cost estimates, and implementation arrangements. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  In the four DMCs, the key agencies concerned with road safety agreed that crashes 
were increasing on their road networks. In many cases, the agencies considered crashes a 
significant threat to life and injury for the local population. Expanding motorization is increasing 
the risk of accidents significantly, particularly since a high percentage of vehicle fleets comprise 
two-wheeled vehicles. In addition, each DMC has a large proportion of vulnerable road users, 
as nonmotorized vehicles, bicycles, and pedestrians compete for road space with motorized 
vehicles. In many urban areas, markets and other economic and social activities also vie for 
road space. In rural areas, roads are frequently used for purposes other than transportation. 
The combination of these factors has increased the overall risk of road crashes significantly, 
and this situation is likely to continue unless steps are taken to mitigate the risks. However, 
policy makers do not have adequate knowledge of the impact of road crashes to implement 
successful countermeasures due to the absence of a proper assessment of the risks and 
identification of the incidence of deaths and injuries.

4.  The impact of a road crash is felt most immediately at the household level. It often has 
an instantaneous impact on household activity, significantly affecting the quality of life. Death of 
the main income earner, cost of medical treatment, and loss of a job and/or income resulting 
from a road crash often have important adverse economic and social consequences on a 
household. For instance, studies in Bangladesh3 have demonstrated that road crashes often 
push  poor  households  into  poverty,  a  condition  from  which  they  have  trouble  recovering. 
Government agencies and WHO officials in the four DMCs agreed that the TA should focus on 
the impact at the household level, particularly the impact on low-income and poverty households 
as they are the most vulnerable.  
 
5.  The absence of a reliable accident data system is a serious constraint in many DMCs. 
Generally, police statistics grossly underreport the seriousness of the road accident situation. As 
a result, the issue is not accorded the national priority it deserves. Two of the countries, 
Pakistan and Viet Nam, undertook injury surveys to identify the incidence of road traffic injuries 
(RTIs). In both countries, the surveys found that RTI is the main cause of noncommunicable 
deaths and injuries, and primarily affects the main economically active group (males 20–45 
years old). In Pakistan, the injury survey concluded that police statistics underreport 18% of 
road traffic fatalities and 75% of injuries. In Viet Nam, the injury survey estimated that the 
annual number of deaths is almost double the official figure at 21,000, while actual injuries are 
35 times the official figure at 1.1 million. The Planning Commission in India assumes that for 
every road death, 15 people are seriously injured and 70 sustain slight injuries. Based on this 
formula, 1.2 million people are seriously injured and 5.6 million are slightly injured each year. In 
Indonesia, another TA4 estimated the number of fatalities at 3.5 times those of police records 
and injuries at almost 200 times police figures, affecting an estimated 2.5 million persons a year. 
Overall, deaths and injuries are significantly higher than official records indicate. This situation 
also highlights the heavy and largely unseen burden on the health sector. Discussions with 
health  sector  officials  corroborate  the  pattern  of  increasing  deaths  and  injuries  from  road 
crashes. The evidence suggests that emergency medical facilities in the four countries lack the 
capacity  to  handle  the  rising  number  of  road  crash  victims  and  increasingly  they  impose 
substantial costs on already overburdened health systems. Identifying the burden on the health 
sector is important in establishing priorities, and formulating health sector budgets and policy on 
emergency services. It also raises the awareness of the debilitating impact of road crashes on 
society. 
 
6.  Vehicle insurance is often considered a way to provide a social safety net for those 
involved in a road crash. However, many vehicles in DMCs are not insured or are under-
insured. As a consequence, RTI victims frequently do not receive adequate compensation. 
Governance issues are another common cause of insurance-related problems. In the four 
DMCs, legislation is in place requiring third party, no-fault insurance as a minimum. Still, a high 
percentage of vehicles are not insured. Premiums are also low. Even in cases where vehicles 
are properly insured, compensation payments are commensurately low and usually insufficient 
to cover medical treatment and other personal costs. In many instances, payments are made 
only after lengthy judicial processes, and not when the funds are needed for medical and other 
costs. In some countries, accident victims do not have any legal recourse. The assessment of 
the socioeconomic impact of road crashes must include an evaluation of the effectiveness of the

vehicle insurance industry and its legal framework, because these are important factors in 
providing a safety net for crash victims.  
 
7.  The proposed TA has been designed to address these concerns. It will fill an important 
gap in the knowledge concerning the socioeconomic impact of road crashes and how they affect 
the lives of poor individuals and households. The TA will help DMCs across the region take 
appropriate countermeasures to address road safety concerns particularly those that have direct 
impact  on  the  poor.  The  findings  are  also  expected  to  enable  the  governments  adopt 
appropriate policies to mitigate the impact of road crashes and thereby improve the quality of life 
of the poor. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The ultimate objective of the TA is to reduce the number and severity of road crashes 
and particularly their impact on low-income households. At present, there is little knowledge in 
the DMCs on the actual impact of road crashes and the information is deficient in determining 
who are typically involved in road crashes and how crash events impact on the lives of people. 
The TA is designed to close the knowledge gap by conducting household surveys designed to 
assess  the  socioeconomic  impact  on  individuals  and  households.  This  information  will  be 
supported by information and data collected from public sector agencies, the private sector, and 
civil society organizations involved with road safety. To assess differences across the region the 
TA will focus on four countries: India, Indonesia, Pakistan, and Viet Nam. The primary purpose 
of the TA is to improve DMCs’ ability to plan and implement road safety measures that will save 
lives and reduce the severity of adverse impact particularly on low-income households. 
 
9.  The main outputs of the TA will include (i) four pro-poor road safety action plans; 
(ii) assessment of the socioeconomic impact of road crashes on households at different income 
levels, with particular focus on poor and poverty households; (iii) an improved knowledge base 
of road crash statistics and a better understanding of linkages between road crashes and 
poverty;  (iv)  an  evaluation  of  the  burden  of  road  crashes  on  the  health  sector;  (v)  an 
assessment of motor vehicle insurance practices; and (vi) knowledge-sharing products and 
events for dissemination of the TA findings across the region.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The TA will document the impact of road crashes on households, their coping strategies, 
and the extent to which they are able to recover. The TA will estimate the cumulative cost to the 
country, as well as the extent of underreporting and the burden of RTI on health care facilities. 
RTI’s contribution to poverty will also be examined as the poor are expected to be more at risk 
for being involved in road crashes. Moreover, they have fewer resources to rely on in times of 
emergency. 
 
11.  The important activities of the TA are the following: 
 
(i)  Inventory health care facilities and rehabilitation services available for road traffic 
victims in the study areas, and assess the burden road crashes place on the 
health sector by surveying the resources allocated to road traffic casualties in 
hospitals and health clinics.

4   
(ii)  Survey  prospective  victim  households  to  document  the  financial  costs  and 
socioeconomic impacts of having a household member killed or injured in a road 
crash. The survey sample will cover metropolitan, urban, and rural households. It 
will be large enough (expected survey size of 600–1,000 households) to identify 
statistically  significant  differences  between  impacts  on  poor  and  non-poor 
households.  The  survey  will  also  include  a  full  range  of  socioeconomic 
characteristics, including gender, ethnicity, and age. Victim households are to be 
identified at random from police records and facilities identified in the health care 
survey. Victim households will be given a diary to record costs and impact, and 
the survey team will return periodically to interview households and collect data 
over a follow-up period of 1 year. 
 
(iii)  Review alternative sources of road casualty data (e.g., health care facilities, 
ambulances, mortuaries, and newspapers), and estimate the incidence of actual 
road traffic injury and extent of underreporting by casualty severity. 
 
(iv)  Collect  data  on  property  damage  costs  of  road  crashes,  and  evaluate  the 
effectiveness of the motor insurance system in providing a safety net for road 
crash victims with particular emphasis on low-income and poverty households.  
 
(v)  Identify  the  link  between  road  crashes  and  poverty,  including  the  risk  of 
involvement and the consequences to households. Transport policies should be 
reviewed to assess the priority that should be given to vulnerable road users and 
bus passengers, and to develop pro-poor national road safety action plans that 
recommend how to reduce risks of road crashes and ameliorate the impact on 
poor households.   
 
(vi)  Calculate the economic cost of road crashes to the nation, and identify who pays 
the cost of road crashes. Produce a video showing personal experiences and 
statistics from study findings. Present findings at a national workshop attended 
by  representatives  of  public  sector  agencies,  private  sector  companies,  civil 
society organizations, and academic institutions.  
 
(vii)  Present and compare findings from the four countries at national and regional 
workshops, national videos, and through a project website. The lessons learned 
will be documented to assist with subsequent studies. The national workshops 
will focus on a discussion of findings and conclusions, with the aim of agreeing 
on the time frame and implementation arrangements for the road safety action 
plan. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The estimated cost of the TA is $1,005,000 equivalent, including foreign exchange cost 
of $537,000 and local currency cost of $468,000. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
PRF and administered by the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The PRF will finance $925,000 
equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost and $388,000 equivalent of the local 
currency cost. The governments of India, Indonesia, Pakistan, and Viet Nam will finance the 
remaining local currency costs of $80,000 by providing counterpart staff, office accommodation, 
and  other  in-kind  expenditures.  The  detailed  cost  estimates  and  financing  plan  are  in 
Appendix 2.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB’s  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department;  Energy,  Transport,  and 
Water Division, will be the executing agency for the TA. A technical steering committee will be 
created within ADB to provide technical oversight. It will consist of transport staff from regional 
departments, as well as poverty specialists, social development specialists, economists, and 
health sector specialists. Within each DMC, a multisector project steering committee will be 
established  headed  by  a  focal  point.  The  focal  points  are  (i)  Ministry  of  Shipping,  Road 
Transport and Highways, Department of Road Transport and Highways in India; (ii) Ministry of 
Communications,  Directorate  General  of  Land  Transport  in  Indonesia;  (iii)  Ministry  of 
Communications,  National  Transport  Research  Centre  in  Pakistan;  and  (iv)  Ministry  of 
Transport, National Transport Safety Committee in Viet Nam. The national project steering 
committees will comprise a mix of public sector agencies involved with road safety, including 
police, health, statistics, transport, and vehicle insurance industry, as well as nongovernment 
organizations, private firms, and academic institutions. In addition, the WHO office in each 
country has agreed to participate actively in the study. 
 
14.  The TA will require 72 person-months of consulting services, comprising 20 person-
months of international consultants and 52 person-months of domestic consultants from the 
participating countries. The consultants will be firms of international consultants in association 
with domestic consultants. They will be engaged using ADB’s quality and cost-based selection 
procedures and in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants based on the 
submission of simplified technical proposals. The website specialist will be hired as an individual 
consultant. The international specialists will include a social survey specialist as team leader, 
road safety specialist, poverty specialist, statistician, and motor vehicle insurance specialist. The 
domestic consultant teams will include a similar range of specialists. Field survey teams will also 
be required in each country to collect the required household survey data and supporting 
information. The outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months, beginning in February 2006 and ending by 
February 2008. For the overall study, the consultants will submit an inception report 4 weeks 
after commencement, followed by brief monthly progress reports. Separate inception reports 
and quarterly progress reports will be submitted for each of the country studies. Final reports for 
each of the country studies, and an overall summary report, will be submitted by the end of the 
services in hard and soft copies. To disseminate the results of the studies, national workshops 
will be conducted in each country. In addition, a regional workshop will be held to ensure broad 
dissemination  to  countries  across  the  region.  A  website  will  also  be  created  to  provide 
information on the study and its progress. To promote the findings of the TA, a video will be 
prepared summarizing the socioeconomic impacts and conclusions.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $925,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund for the purpose of Socioeconomic 
Impact of Road Crashes, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  consulting  services  will  include  20  person-months  of  international  expertise, 
including a social survey specialist (the team leader), poverty specialist, statistician, and motor 
vehicle  insurance  compensation  specialist.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  also  include 
52 person-months of domestic consultants with similar skill disciplines. Field survey teams will 
support the domestic consultant teams. 
 
A.  Social Survey Specialist (team leader, 12 person-months) 
 
2.  The team leader will work closely with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) supervising 
staff, as well as relevant national and regional institutions from Government, the private sector, 
and civil society organizations to ensure timely implementation of the TA. The team leader will 
have  primary  responsibility  for  reviewing  previous  studies,  surveying  household,  and 
coordinating and supervising the work of the other consultants and counterpart staff. The team 
leader will also liaise with national, regional, and international road safety organizations, as well 
as organizations such as the Global Road Safety Partnership, World Health Organization, and 
the Global Forum for Health Research. The tasks will include the following: 
 
(i)  Provide leadership on the design of (a) the prospective survey methodology, 
including sample selection and number and timing of follow-up interviews; (b) the 
questionnaire  to  cover  collision  circumstances,  household  socioeconomic 
characteristics,  economic  costs,  social  impacts,  disability  and  quality  of  life 
assessment,  coping  strategies,  and  consequences;  and  (c)  a  logbook  for 
households to record expenses and impacts. The team leader will also advise on 
the training of survey staff and the required quality control checks, and monitor 
the progress of surveys. 
(ii)  Identify  alternative  road  traffic  injury  data  sources,  and  determine  the 
methodology to be used in assessing the extent of underreporting in official road 
casualty statistics. 
(iii)  Assess and agree on the data to be collected from the hospitals and health care 
centers on services provided for the injured; and the medical costs and resources 
expended on road traffic victims, including rehabilitation, to produce an inventory 
of medical services in the study area and assess the burden of road traffic injury 
on the health sector.    
(iv)  Supervise  national  coordination  by  domestic  consultants,  and  ensure  proper 
communication system with national steering committee. The team leader will 
also  develop  and  implement  monitoring  system  to  facilitate  timely  project 
delivery,  and  will  guide  and  direct  the  other  consultants  and  associated 
institutions in all matters pertaining to TA implementation. 
(v)  Coordinate the production of videos presenting local case studies and statistics 
to publicize the country study findings. 
(vi)  Supervise  the  organization  of  national  workshop(s),  including  the  content, 
location,  program,  participants,  and  speakers.  A  main  objective  of  the 
workshop(s) will be to agree on implementation arrangements for the action 
plans and key recommendations. The team leader will also arrange external 
resource persons, if required, and oversee production of workshop proceedings. 
Guidance will also be given on the smaller workshops to be organized by the 
local consultants at the inception and pilot stages. 
(vii)  Determine, in conjunction with domestic consultants, the structure and content of 
national reports, particularly the final report, and other project outputs. The team

the country and the burden on the poor; and will develop a pro-poor national 
action plan, prepare the proceedings of the regional workshop, and an appendix

national findings and conclusions shall be shared among participants from Asia.  
(ix)  Supervise, in conjunction with ADB, the development of the project website, and 
publish project reports and other related materials on the website.  
(x)  Deliver project reports.  
 
B.   Road Crash Costing Specialist (3 person-months) 
 
3.  The road crash costing specialist will have the following responsibilities. 
 
(i)  Advise  on  data  collection  of  road  crashes,  casualties,  motor  vehicle,  road 
network, and socioeconomic indicators for inclusion in a situational review on 
road safety. 
(ii)  Guide the methodology for estimating the crash cost components, e.g., value of 
life, property damage, and administration costs (including data sources, analysis, 
and calculations to be undertaken). 
(iii)  Supervise  the  estimation  of  the  number  of  road  crashes,  including  those 
unreported to the police, and the calculation of the cost to the country.   
(iv)  Advise on the identification of key transport policies and plans to be assessed 
based on the priority given to vulnerable road users. 
(v)  Coordinate the development of a pro-poor road safety action plan, including 
identification  of  opportunities  for  increased  investment  in  road  safety  from 
national  sources  and  externally  assisted  projects;  and  preparation  of  an 
implementation strategy for action plan approval. 
(vi)  Provide  a  summary  of  lessons  learned,  and  recommend  changes  for  future 
studies estimating socioeconomic impacts of road crashes. 
(vii)  Participate in national and regional workshops where findings are presented, 
including a proposed pro-poor road safety action plan.  
 
C.   Poverty Specialist (1.5 person-months) 
 
4.  The poverty specialist will have the following responsibilities. 
 
(i)  Guide local consultants on the working definition of poverty to be used in the 
study  to  ensure  consistency  with  official  national  definitions.  The  poverty 
specialist will also assess the practicality of using an income-, expenditure-, or 
asset-based approach. 
(ii)  Advise on socioeconomic data to be collected in household surveys to ensure 
accurate and consistent identification of the poor at precrash and postcrash 
stages. 
(iii)  Analyze household survey findings to determine the impact on poverty levels and 
differences between poor and nonpoor households. 
(iv)  Provide feedback at the pilot stage on the practicality of the poverty definition 
being used, and respond to any poverty-related queries by other consultants and 
the team leader.   
(v)  Contribute to the development of the pro-poor road safety plan, and provide 
examples of other pro-poor policies.

(vi)  Provide a summary of lessons learned, recommend changes for future studies, 
and provide inputs into the road safety action plan. 
 
D.  Statistician (2.5 person-months) 
 
5.  The statistician will have the following responsibilities. 
 
(i)  Provide technical advice and guidance on the household survey methodology to 
be undertaken to assess the socioeconomic impact of road crashes and identify 
any  significant  differences  between  poor  and  nonpoor  households.  This  will 
include specifying the background research required, and designing the sampling 
frame to produce a representative sample of victim households selected from 
police and hospital data sources. 
(ii)  Advise on survey methodologies to be used to assess underreporting, the burden 
on health sector, and the property damage costs from road crashes. 
(iii)  Monitor survey progress and provide feedback after the pilot stage and monthly 
progress reports. The statistician will also develop data entry procedures with 
appropriate consistency checks. 
(iv)  Advise and supervise data analysis, interpretation, and summarization of survey 
data, e.g., household, health care, insurance, and transport operators. 
(v)  Provide  a  summary  of  lessons  learned,  and  how  to  improve  the  statistical 
analysis in future costing studies. 
 
E.    Motor Insurance Compensation Specialist (1 person-month) 
6.  The motor insurance compensation specialist will have the following responsibilities. 
 
 (i)  Advise on data to be collected to assess the sufficiency of motor insurance 
compensation, especially for low-income households. Key areas to be covered 
include  (a)  compensation  procedures,  (b)  duration  and  amount  of  claim 
settlement,  (c)  victims  of  collisions  involving  hit-and-run  or  uninsured  motor 
vehicles, (d) public awareness of motor insurance compensation, (e) comparison 
with compensation for other victims of crime and disaster, and (f) insurance 
reform. 
(ii)  Document good practice examples of motor insurance compensation in low- and 
middle-income countries.  
(iii)  Provide feedback on national reports on motor insurance compensation, and 
guidance on the way forward in improving motor insurance compensation. The 
specialist will also respond to any motor insurance compensation-related queries 
by other consultants or the team leader. 
(iv)  Provide a summary of how motor insurance compensation reviews could be 
improved, and inputs into the road safety action plan. 
 
F.  Domestic Consultants (52 person-months) 
 
7.  The four domestic consultant teams will include social survey specialists, road safety 
specialists, statisticians, motor insurance specialists, and public health researchers. The team 
leader is expected to be a social survey specialist with experience in costing injury or illness. 
Field survey teams for data and information gathering will assist the domestic consultants. The 
domestic consultants will be responsible for tasks outlined in paras. 8–10.

1.  Project Management and Household Survey 
 
8.  The consultants will carry out the following. 
 
(i)  Obtain all approvals required for research to be conducted from police, hospitals, 
health  care  centers,  state  and  national  authorities,  and  medical  research 
councils.  
(ii)  Review  existing  data  sources,  related  studies,  materials,  and  background 
information for potential use in the study. 
(iii)  Employ and train survey staff in interview techniques, questionnaire completion, 
and data checking procedures. The consultants will also develop quality controls 
and supervise survey staff throughout the survey.  
(iv)  Inventory  hospital  and  health  care  facilities  in  the  study  area  to  document 
medical  services  available  for  road  crash  victims.  The  consultants  will  also 
produce a simple directory of medical services in the study area, which will be 
shared with injured and bereaved families.    
(v)  Develop  survey  methodology  to  identify  a  representative  sample  of  victim 
households  from  police  and  hospital  records.  These  will  include  households 
where someone has been killed, seriously injured, or slightly injured in a road 
crash. 
(vi)  Conduct background research on official poverty definition for the study area, 
and the use of income-, expenditure- and asset-based poverty classification.   
(vii)  Design  questionnaires  for  the  prospective  household  survey  covering 
socioeconomic details, including pre- and postcrash income of the household, 
crash  circumstances,  expenses  and  opportunity  costs  incurred,  disabilities, 
coping strategy, and impacts on the household. The consultants will also produce 
a logbook for households to record crash-related expenses and impacts, e.g., 
medicine and treatment costs, work or school days missed, and days spent 
recovering or seeking new employment. 
(viii)  Organize inception workshop for discussion of research objectives and proposed 
survey  methodology.  The  workshop  will  include  police,  transport/road  safety 
officials, public health/medical professionals, civil society, private firms, academic 
institutions, and the national steering committee.  
(ix)  Conduct a pilot survey of at least 50 victim households randomly selected from 
police and hospital records. The consultants will present the findings at the pilot 
workshop, and review effectiveness and practicality of survey methodology. 
(x)  Contact remaining victim households and conduct follow-up surveys over 1 year 
from  initial  contact.  The  number  of  victim  households  to  be  interviewed  is 
estimated at 600–1,000, covering urban, metropolitan, and rural locations; and 
with different casualty severities (bereaved, seriously, and slightly injured) and 
income characteristics, including a focus on low-income and poverty households.  
(xi)  Organize  and  supervise  survey  data  entry,  and  analyze  survey  findings  to 
determine the costs associated with road crashes, the risk of involvement, and 
impact of road crashes on households. The consultants will highlight significant 
differences between poor and nonpoor households. 
(xii)  Assist with the production of a video highlighting the impact of road crashes by 
identifying victims willing to participate, and providing study findings to be used in 
video. 
(xiii)  Organize  a  national  workshop  for  discussion  of  study  findings  and 
recommendations, and launch of the video. A major objective of the national

(xiv)  Contribute to a regional workshop by recommending national delegates, and 
providing presentations or coordinating discussion sessions, if required. 
(xv)  Collect data on treatment of road traffic injuries at hospitals and health care 
centers, including the number and share of total patients treated and resource 
costs, e.g., number of bed days or operations for traffic injuries. 
(xvi)  Provide monthly progress reports to the international team leader, and provide

2.  Road Safety and Crash Costing 
 
9.  The consultants will do the following. 
 
(i)  Obtain statistics on road crashes, casualties, motor vehicles, road length, and 
kilometers traveled; and compile them in a situational report on road safety. 
(ii)  Review key transport policies, including road safety plans or strategies, to assess 
the priority given to vulnerable road users. 
(iii)  Contact  vehicle  damage  and  administration  data  sources,  e.g.,  transport 
operators, insurance companies, police records. The consultants will collect data 
on damage costs by crash severity, and estimate incidence of damage-only 
collisions. 
(iv)  Identify any research on calculation of human costs with other diseases, e.g., 
HIV/AIDS.1 
(v)  Estimate  the  cost  of  road  crashes,  including  casualty-related  costs  from 
household surveys (lost output and medical costs), human costs, and crash-
related costs (property damage and administration costs).  
(vi)  Develop a pro-poor road safety action plan that includes proposals to reduce the 
risk of road crashes to low-income households. 
 
3.  Motor Insurance Compensation 
 
10.  The consultants will do the following. 
 
(i)  Identify  and  interview  key  officials,  e.g.,  motor  insurance  tribunal,  insurance 
commission, insurance association, social welfare/disability ministry, and police 
on  the  problems  associated  with  motor  vehicle  insurance,  particularly  the 
problems that poor households might face in obtaining fair and timely insurance 
compensation.   
(ii)  Collect insurance claim data to identify frequency, claim amounts, and duration of 
claims involving pedestrians, cyclists, and bus passengers.   
(iii)  Produce an assessment report on the motor insurance compensation system to 
assist the poor after a road crash.
